pages.text: Nimbia occlusa hails from the Cryogenian into the lower-most Cambrian, with fossils found in the Blueflower Formation, Canada; White Sea, Russia; White Mountains, USA; Kurgan Formaion, Kazakhstan, and the Booley Bay Formation, Ireland. It is a small discoid organism, groung up to 6 cm in diameter. They have a thick outer margin, with a noticeable dimple in the middle of some fossil material. Like most discoid forms, they are considered to be cnidarians, although

some consider them to be made from microbial colonies. Due to their widespread occurrences across the northern hemisphere and large range of time, it has been speculated that Nimbia may consist of more than a single species, the only one being N. occlusa.
